body:
sum is technically the only one you need, isArray (Array.isArray), toJSON
(JSON.stringify?), and log (console.log and/or Math.log) are supplied by
other environments.  But really emit is the only mandatory one, PouchDB
only has emit and sum and literally nobody has complained (I'm probably
going to open an issue on that though now).   A better idea for the other
functions might be to execute the map function bound so that the `this`
value has sum, toJSON, isArray, sum, and log as methods.

On Tue, Jan 21, 2014 at 7:05 PM, Alexander Shorin
notifications@github.comwrote:

> I'm not sure that this change is reasonable. Yes, it makes views code
> become less depended on global functions, but emit isn't the only that
> available: see sandboxhttps://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/share/server/loop.js#L19for all available context. So even if you allow to redefine the
> emit, some views may use toJSON, isArray, log and sum so you still have
> to run such views within context where these functions are available - I'm
> not sure that you'd like to see all of them as function arguments.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/127#issuecomment-32979290
> .

## 

-Calvin W. Metcalf
I like it from a best practices stand point. Its a little cleaner to pass the emit in. However other than making Pouchdb not need `eval` I don't really see the benefit.

Hey @BigBlueHat,

Thanks for this. We are going to have to change the way we do this. We need to add this functionality as a plugin that is a seperate module that hooks in as an [extensions](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/src/fauxton/extensions.md). Not all couchdb instances that run Fauxton are capable of running different languages eg Pouchdb-server and Cloudant.

The other advantage of making this a module is that we could add full support for Ruby, Python and Erlang.

my other thought had been so you could rename emit, like if you were
reusing code for something.  I could also see it as a pattern in general
which would make it easier to write a query server for a language that
doesn't support closures.

On Wed, Jan 22, 2014 at 2:31 AM, garren smith notifications@github.comwrote:

> I like it from a best practices stand point. Its a little cleaner to pass
> the emit in. However other than making Pouchdb not need eval I don't
> really see the benefit.

## 

-Calvin W. Metcalf
@garrensmith @deathbearbrown I think my last commit uses `establish()` as intended. :grin: Let me know if not.
@BigBlueHat That looks right. Nice.

Status report for anyone watching (/me glances over at @kxepal).

@garrensmith and I are discussing making this a Fauxton extension and/or part of the Config addon. As it is now, it tangles the addons a bit and makes Documents unusable with pouchdb-server, Cloudant's Dashboard, and anyone else who might have a CouchDB API supporting product, but no `/_config/` endpoint.

Making it an extension should also lay the ground work for Ruby, Python, and Erlang query servers + templates, etc.

Stay tuned. :radio:

,,,^..^,,,
Closed as the code has become part of [PR 138](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/138).
why using a process? You don't really need it since the recv can wwait and you're already in a request process.

This may be my ignorance. As far as I could see, the recv_chunked function doesn't wait: it just reads its content and calls the ChunkFun for each chuck. So the process is there to force waiting. If you can point me to a way to make it wait, that would obviously be much better, and I'll be happy to implement it.
why not passing a callback to a multipart decode function?

also, did you removed support for the content-length encoding? 

The use of a spawned process is somehow a blocker for me. We shouldn't have to spawn a process to receive the data here. instead recv() from the socket and pass it to the stream API.  One way to handle that is to ask more data if we didn't get the end of the chunk.

I am also not sure what happen when a bad multipart request is given. Seems like we would return a 500 error.

@NorthNick Looks pretty good in general. The only major things I can find are mostly stylistic. The indentation is off in places though this can be hard to learn given that lots of couchdb doesn't really use a consistent style.

The bigger thing is that you've put all of this work into a single commit on this PR. I'd much prefer to see two or three commits that are descriptive in what's being changed. For instance, the fact that you called out three distinct pieces of work in your 1956Notes.txt on COUCHDB-1956 suggests that you're mixing work that shouldn't be. While one vs three commits may seem trivial it really helps during code review when specific changes aren't intermingled.

You should also try and include more information in your commit messages. You wrote some intro on the PR but none of that is in the commit message itself. If I ever look back at history I'd have to read the actual diff to remind myself what was changed. Tim Pope has a good article on writing commit messages [1].

Other than that, the actual code changes are mostly fine from what I can tell. I haven't done more than read but assuming it builds and passes all tests I would be ok merging the work with bit of cleanup for things I mentioned.

So +1 after some style cleanup.

[1] http://tbaggery.com/2008/04/19/a-note-about-git-commit-messages.html

@davisp mmm maybe a bug then, the show inline note doesn't disable them from the diff view on my browser. Thanks for the hint anyway :)

@NorthNick I will play with that code tomorrow. I understand the intention of the current code anyway. I would prefer to not have to spawn another process just because the current API doesn't allow it. I will report in the utc afternoon.

Of course it would be a lot easier to use a parser like the one in hackney [1] which allows stuff like :

but that's out of question for now.

Looks as something awesome! But I'll just leave a reminder about license headers for new files and `src/Makefile.am` update for added/removed files (;

@kxepal Thanks for the reminder. :smile: 

The only new files (iirc) are the `styletests` addon (which @deathbearbrown originally wrote). Shouldn't need a license file as it falls under commits made by one of us--both of whom fall under the Apache CLA (i.e. it's not an external vendor thing, but a straight commit of new code).

Let me know if I'm off somewhere, or need to add something. :smiley: 

Thanks!
@BigBlueHat If there are new files, they need to be added to Makefile.am in the above folder directory otherwise `make distcheck` will fail.

They're only used in the context of `grunt dev` and should be avoided by any `dist` related stuff--as we don't want them landing in a distribution in this case.

Do I still need to tell the `src/Makefile.am` about them in that case?

On @davisp's comments on the number of commits and commit comments: you are completely right. Some Git difficulties led to everything being in one commit, but I will split it up and write sensible comments as suggested before it hits the main repository.
Also, +1 on squashing these at merge time.

> Shouldn't need a license file as it falls under commits made by one of us--both of whom fall under the Apache CLA (i.e. it's not an external vendor thing, but a straight commit of new code).

Actually, all files should contains explicitly ASF license header or be added to `/license.skip` otherwise if they are ships under some other license (with mention in `/LICENSE` and `/NOTICE` files). You may run `make distcheck` to prove this by yourself (:

Did and fixed. See newer commit log.

Alexander Shorin notifications@github.com wrote:

Shouldn't need a license file as it falls under commits made by one of us--both of whom fall under the Apache CLA (i.e. it's not an external vendor thing, but a straight commit of new code).

Actually, all files should contains explicitly ASF license header or be added to /license.skip otherwise if they are ships under some other license (with mention in /LICENSE and /NOTICE files). You may run make distcheck to prove this by yourself (:

I tidied this up, restoring the MAX_URI_LEN constant (since it was repeated), introducing a minimum value beyond which we give up, and providing an optional ability to tell couchdb to reject uri's over a certain length (useful for testing this negotiation but also useful to align couchdb limits with a proxy's limit).

An alternative is to use ES5 shim instead, which should fix other errors where functions on the ES5 Array.prototype and other things like .bind() are used.

https://github.com/es-shims/es5-shim

It´s licensed with The MIT License.

Thats actually a better idea and should hopefully prevent any other issues. @ziggythehamster could you change this PR to rather include the es5-shim. You will also have to add the licensing to `LICENSE` and `NOTICE`. There are plenty of examples in those files to help you. You will also have to add the es5-shim to `license.skip`

Erhm...this may sounds awkward and everyone will recall one good joke from StackOverflow site, but why not to use jQuery instead? (:

[$.inArray](http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.inArray/)

Garren Smith replies:
Also a good approach. It would just require finding all the instances of `indexOf` and replacing with `$.inArray`
We are deleting Futon entirely, maybe we should just bring that forward to the next release and put Fauxton in its rightful place?

One of the benefits with jQuery is that it just works in all older and modern browsers (if you are using 1.9.x that is). The drawback is that you will not the same performance as the built-in functions.

You can test $.inArray() and Array.prototype.indexOf here:
http://jsperf.com/in-array-vs-inarray-vs-indexof

If you can use the native methods, you should do that.

And if we take a look at the ES5 support in browsers, we can see that IE 8 is the last version of IE that doesn't have full support for this (IE 9 supports everything except strict mode, which it will just ignore):
http://kangax.github.io/es5-compat-table/

Since IE 8 is the latest version that can be installed on Windows XP, and Microsoft is not going to support Windows XP after april this year, I guess CouchDB shouldn't have to either.

Is it really that important to support a browser that not even Microsoft is going to support in 1½ month?

Nick North replies:
--047d7b15a96bc8a62504f2c04a80
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

> One of the benefits with jQuery is that it just works in all older and modern browsers (if you are using 1.9.x that is). The drawback is that you will not the same performance as the built-in functions.
> 
> You can test $.inArray() and Array.prototype.indexOf here:
> http://jsperf.com/in-array-vs-inarray-vs-indexof

really, I don't think that performance is matters in place of locating user role in the list that almost always has 1-2-3 elements, max 10 elements.

> Is it really that important to support a browser that not even Microsoft is going to support in 1½ month?

Good point, but we couldn't just remove Futon without breaking compatibility (there are couchapps that depends on his js libs). Also we'll probably have to keep some LTS release for some time when 2.0 will be done. Moreover, people are lazy and if they have no serious reasons they wouldn't reinstall OS with all the software on it and support end deadline will not make all IE8 disappear in the moment. And this fix looks not so much complex to let him in (:

> really, I don't think that performance is matters in place of locating user role in the list that almost always has 1-2-3 elements, max 10 elements.

Absolutely, but when you can use the standardized methods, I think you should. :) Another solution would be to use [underscore](http://underscorejs.org/), but I still prefer Array.prototype.indexOf in this case (and use the shim in older browsers).
@janl what say ye?
should be trivial to find out whether this was merged.
It wasn't. The second commit is not on master.

Nick North north.n@gmail.com on "dev@couchdb.apache.org" dev@couchdb.apache.org replies:
I also initially took the view that CouchDb should not have to support IE8,
as Microsoft won't. But searching around shows that Windows 7 initially
came with IE8, which puts it under the same support cycle as Windows 7,
meaning there are years of pain yet to suffer.

Ahh, forgot that Windows 7 was shipped with IE 8. Well, then I guess there must be support for it.

I still suggest that ES5 shim and similar should be used where the browser doesn't support a specific API. If the user is using any of the modern browsers, they should get the best experience possible, while users with older browsers should still be able to use it.

Mixing different frameworks just because you can could easily lead to confused developers in the end. ECMAScript 5th Edition has this indexOf function, and since it´s possible to shim it, I don't see any reason for why anything else should be used.

@garrensmith - I like the ES5 Shim much better. I'll update this PR with the ES5 Shim and the license.skip change to make Travis happy.

@everyone else - This fix is needed to support IE8 on Windows 7, which someone on the user@ mailing list requested.

Great. Looking forward to it.

Let's merge this and not wait for a heavier change for this on-it's-way-out project.

The licensing for array.indexof.js is public domain:

> Code samples added on or after August 20, 2010 are in the public domain. No licensing notice is necessary, but if you need one, you can use: "Any copyright is dedicated to the Public Domain. http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/".

Per: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Project:MDN/About#Copyrights_and_licenses

On the list several people said "patches welcome." A patch arrives and the conversation spins off into all the various options for re-implementing this same feature. Apache CouchDB can't afford to have this keep happening. It's exhausting.

@rnewson @garrensmith @kxepal please consider merging this sooner than later to keep this community awesome. :smile: 

Fauxton is still some ways out from feature parity and will have it's own set of issues with old browsers.

Just input from a concerned citizen. :innocent:
How did you date the code sample in question to after August 20, 2010?

It's really not a huge deal to change the patch to do ES5-Shim. How would I handle the licensing bit?

https://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/153#issuecomment-35515126

Also, I'm told Fauxton _has_ feature parity today. Is that untrue? If so, what's missing?

Supporting Futon _and_ Fauxton is a burden, and preserving Futon reduces the pressure to fix Fauxton's missing features, whatever they may be.

@BigBlueHat I understand your frustration. But we need to find a balance between merging quickly and making sure they the right patch for Couchdb. As @ziggythehamster said adding the es5-shim is not much more work and I think a much better addition. So I would prefer to see that added instead. At this stage we know that `indexOf` fails in one section. But we don't know if there are other features failing in other pages. Adding the shim should cover us.

@ziggythehamster in terms of licensing. Just add the es5-shim license to the files NOTICE and LICENSE. Add the es5-shim file to license.skip. Plenty of examples in those files to help.

> @rnewson @garrensmith @kxepal please consider merging this sooner than later to keep this community awesome. :smile:

I'm fine with any solution, just wanted to note, that for such trivial fix there is no need to get yet another library into the code base when there is possible to easily reuse existed functionality to make things just works. I understand position about to seek in the perfect solution, but Futon is not the case any more to care about performance, features, purity of the implementation or something. That was my 5 cents.
Ok I'm happy with the $.indexOf fix. It is the easiest fix.
